Lmao just came across Jim Cramer's [The Winners of the New World Top 10 must own stocks back in 2000:](https://www.thestreet.com/personal-finance/the-winners-of-the-new-world-891820)

"We try to own every one of them. Every single one. And if I had my druthers, I wouldn't own any other stocks in the year 2000. Because these are the only ones worth owning right now in this extremely difficult, extremely narrow stock market. They are the only ones that are going higher consistently in good days and bad. I love every one of them, just as I loathe the rest of the stock universe. "

724 Solutions(SVNX)
Ariba (ARBA)
Digital Island (ISLD)
Exodus (EXDS)
InfoSpace.com (INSP)
Inktomi (INKT)
Mercury Interactive (MERQ)
Sonera (SNRA)
VeriSign (VRSN)
Veritas Software (VRTS)

author: RipeForInvesting
body:
Since this is an investing forum, let's forget whether it is or isn't blown out of proportion and look how the markets have reacted to the news.

Since Friday, we have more cases, more people dead (one on our home turf).  The worse part is they currently believe it could have been cryptically circulating in Washington for six weeks now.  About the best news, I've seen is the number of cases in China has slowed, at least if you believe them.

So, the things that triggered the correction have only gotten worse.  Hence why I said this week will most likely be redder.  There very well could be another announcement like you got from Apple/Mastercard/etc as icing on the cake.  

I'm personally not that concerned about the illness itself.  I am more concerned about potential disruptions.  It could seriously put a hurt on your income and life regardless.  I work in the school system part-time and if they were to say close a school down for two weeks, well there goes that income.  It goes beyond catching the illness itself.

I live in Atlanta, about 30 mins from Jackson Hartsfield, I can tell you that Georgia has been already making lots of preparations (I'm surprised because normally our state is four steps behind).

author: oregon_forever
body: I love how everyone compares this to 2008. This is nothing like that. In 2008 crisis, millions of people were on the verge of losing their homes and becoming homeless, every street had a few foreclosed homes, our biggest banks and financial institutions were on the verge of bankruptcy and needed bailing out, our 3 big car companies were losing billions and about to go bankrupt, every day thousands of people were getting laid off, we had unemployment rate going in double digits, small companies were going bankrupt right and left, it felt like this was the end of capitalism and the whole system was collapsing under its own weight. Now what do we have? Possibly 3-6 months of supply chain disruptions. Oh please!

author: Bartlet4America94
body:
Copying my comment regarding RH suits:

If you file in court, they’ll move to dismiss, since the “proper” venue is via a FINRA arbitration. 

A bunch of these popping up will cause headaches, but it’ll probably be a copy-paste type motion to dismiss, so it won’t cost them that much $. Lack of PJ, improper venue, even SJ since it’s all federal securities (though many states have their own securities regulatory bodies).

Now, there are jurx that don’t follow mandatory arbitration (LA, NC) so technically those RH users in these states could file and not necessarily get bumped out on the MtD phase. However, since this is mainly federal stuff, I still think most courts will defer to FINRA.

The main strategy would be to file in court and then immediately leverage settlement before the judge rules on dismissal. Settlement for each individual case would be low and so would be the bargaining power of the potential plaintiff. You’d want to consolidate all actions into a class. The problem with this is it takes time and then you’ll have fights over class cert. that can move the settlement needle back and forth.

author: throwaway_0x90
body:
I'm not going to even pretend that I have strong hands. I was forced to hold over the weekend by 2 personal policies I established before all this craziness:
* Don't use market orders
* Don't make decisions in panic situations

I tried to sell my SPY puts(SPXS calls) during the last 2 minutes of Friday market but the price kept falling below the limit price I set. Then I tried to find news of why the sudden SPY spike was happening. Couldn't find it and barely had 45 seconds to market close so I just gave up and said to myself: _"Whatever, I'm going down with the ship"_.

It's only now that my sinking ship is looking more like a space shuttle preparing for take off.

author: Salty_Cornflakes
body:
To all those crying about the death of WSB, here is a mod's response:

 

* We're working on it. We've made a few adjustments already that have helped immensely. I'd wager that 4/5 of the posts that you're complaining about don't even see the light of day. Which should impress and terrify you.
* It's difficult trying to strike a balance. The public attention has brought a lot of legitimate traders here who just want to share their experience, real DD, technical analysis, etc and we want to encourage that. They obviously make new accounts and we want them to contribute immediately.
* We're tweaking things everyday in response to rapidly changing growth and news that swings the entire sub in a matter of hours (like our pumping problem last week). This weeked now everyone is talking about their local Costco, committing bioterroism, and killing the pope. Also, please calm the fuck down with killing the pope, guys. It's borderline enciting violence, I've temp banned a few people who take it wayyyy too far.
* Our sexuality aside, we're volunteers from around the world. Our hours and availability differ, so there are mod lulls where a lot of one liner shitposts get through. We do our best, but we really focus on providing the best experience we can for you guys during trading hours when the engagement here is through the roof.
* As far as you or others wanting to volunteer, you guys actually do a pretty good job en mass with downvoting and reporting bullshit. Keep it up. We appreciate that.

That's all I got at the moment. Hope it gives you some kind of something.

author: Sikeitsryan
body:
since no ones helped you out

options are contracts entered into by you and someone else (a counter party). There's 2 types of options, puts and calls. If you look at OP's picture you'll see that one of his "trades" is for SQQQ $29 CALL 3/20.

So he wants to buy a call. Now, like I said this call is a contract between OP and someone else. This contract states that at anytime between the day that OP purchases the call contract and the expiration date of the contract, stated as 3/20/2020. OP has the 'option' or choice to buy 100 shares of the etf SQQQ from the counter party of the contract for $29 regardless of what the actual price of the ETF is.

&#x200B;

So theoretically, if on 3/15 SQQQ is trading at $50 a share, OP can exercise his option and buy those 100 shares for $29 dollars from the counter party and sell those shares immediately in the open market for $50. 

&#x200B;

The downside is that OP has to pay the counter party a 'premium' in order to have this option. Right now the premium has a bid/ask of $2.65 x 2.95. So if OP wants to buy the call he has to pay $2.95 x 100 (per share, remember the call gives op the right to buy 100 shares from the counter party). Now, you may be asking, why is the spread so wide? Wouldn't OP immediately lose $30 or 10% on his trade? Is OP gambling with probably zero actual insight on investing? I'll let you figure those out on your own.

author: Acoconutting
body:
60,000 people died of the flue two years ago with 45 million infected.

Right now there’s 88000 people infected and 3k deaths of Corona virus.


Just to put that in perspective... if this affects as many people as the flu two years ago, we’d expect 1.5 million deaths in the US, or .4% of our total population.

Which likely means people you know would die, considering you likely know more than 30 or so people.

So yeah I dunno why anyone could be downplaying this.

Puts and calls aside... the news is going to get worse

author: DarklyAdonic
body:
Because good news could have come over the weekend.   But it didn't.  Shits only getting worse.  2000 new cases worldwide and Trump has his head stuck up his ass pretending there isnt a problem. 

The only thing insulating the American public from a full blown panic right now is the fact that we have less testing capabilities than pretty much any developed country so we won't realize what's happening until we get to Wuhan levels of fuckery

author: shuusin
body: I agree with many of your points, but the market effects of the virus isn't going to slam all at once. Last week was chaos due in part to the virus, but it was also an incredible market looking for a reason to correct. Personally I'm mostly cash with some long term puts (which already are ITM) waiting for a decent bounce to relieve the IV since the premium on puts is insane right now.

author: Just_Like_FIRE
body: Fidelity supports fractional share buying now, but I think you have to do it through the app. It gives you an option to specify dollars instead of shares.

author: WrongWeekToQuit
body:
Fidelity has some interesting tools that look for profitable options, showing you profit and max loss, and provide probability of assignment, etc.  Gives you a good, better, best sort of choice with in/near and out of the money options to choose from.  

As much as I like pictures, I think for setting up an option trade, you want numbers and probabilities.  Also, a tool like you're suggesting, that isn't hooked up to my trading platform, isn't as handy.

body:

author: armovetz
body:
Edited: i live in US and using USA etrade account ,just in case

**How do i buy just 1.358 part of VOO for dollar cost average strategy?**

First of all let me hooray myself on my first ever post-comment on reddit, thank you :)

I'm slowly getting into investing, portfolio, all that being-super-funny-at-parties things.

Let's say i have Etrade account and i love VOO by Vanguard.Let's say i want contribute $500 per month towards my billionaire future using **dollar cost averaging**

I didn't find any option/button how i can buy **1.5** of VOO, or **0.35** of VOO, or **1.7891** of VOO.

Let's assume VOO jumps between $230 - $320 whatever.So each time i can only buy 1 or 2 of VOO. Doesn't seem to be dollar average strategy.

Is it Etrade limitation? Any other platform (Schwab, fidelity) will give me that option?Is it VOO (any etf, any stock at all??) limitation? (i doubt since every second article in web mentions VOO example for dollar cost averaging)

I've tried google some stuff, and i found some article mentioning some limitations of etrade (if i remember correctly).

It would be awesome if someone can guide me to some 101 noobs article about buying whole/parts of stocks/etf opportunities.

Thanks for reading long post, it's not 9gag, thus no veggies ;)

author: Jwceltic5
body: I know Fidelity does partial shares. That or opening a Schwab account and putting however much money you want in one of their no minimum mutual funds are your best options.

author: Hollisb1001
body: Vanguard, Charles Schwab, and Fidelity are all good low cost to free brokerages. The biggest advantage for me right now with Fidelity, they already have the option to buy fractional shares. Also since my primary mode of investment is index mutual funds, they have the best option for those with their zero funds.

body:

I do bank with Fidelity!

author: TRADE_FUTURES
body: There are already target date retirement funds that do exactly that. Schwab, fidelity, Vanguard all have them.

author: cobras89
body: Isn't it really only Fidelity? Schwab, TD and Robinhood don't have them yet.

author: The-Invisible-Handy
body: Already available in Robinhood (and a bunch of the other app-based brokers), and Schwab started their rollout as well (they actually announced before Fidelity did).  TD had mentioned road mapping it prior to the Schwab deal, now it figures to be a matter of time.

author: Harbor-Freight
body: Plenty of brokers do.  I use TD Ameritrade.  It carries a 6.95 transaction fee for OTC stocks.  Fidelity and Schwab are free.   FYI even some major companies who do meet the size requirements for major markets still choose to trade pink sheet OTC, like Nintendo for example.

author: iknowiamwright
body:
I am very new to the stock market. I actually had some extra income due to this situation as I work for some wealthy individuals and they asked for some extra help right when the issue hit, but I have to pay off a credit card with 0% interest until November. So I have 10k in assets right now, and 10k that needs to be paid off in November. I am 35 with a family, and we expect to be able to save $1400 per month moving forward as well which includes paying my car payment at 3%, but I live rent free (so I will be able to have another $8.4k to pay off the card). I also have retirement already and put enough in there, so I am not too worried about that. I placed a bit of money in Tesla for 1 week (a friend of mine got in really low talks about it all the time) and I removed it after making some money, just at the right time. I realize I was lucky and want to make the right decisions moving forward. Being as I can make enough to pay off most of my debt, I feel I could be a bit risky. I was contemplating placing about 1k or 2k into the market as I could still double down another 2k if the market goes way down, and then again if it goes down further. Is this the right strategy? 10-20% now knowing I could make that money back by investing more if it crashes? What else should I know? Should I do a Roth IRA now for 2k, or wait until my finances settle....

Lastly, I have been using Fidelity as they are already my bank. I like their website, hate their app. I am not locked in to using their services. I tried using Uplift on my phone just to track stocks... hated it. I have heard good things about Sigfig, but did not realize it was not more than a stock tracker and they wanted all my info. Any suggestions on the best app to possibly invest, but at least track stocks would be amazing. I want to do my research. I want to be able to see ratings, graphs,

author: carolina0000FFs
body: You can also trade index funds on Robinhood by purchasing ETFs. However, Robinhood is a less mature investment platform. It's popular with people just getting started, but it has had a lot of bugs and outages and lacks good features for long term investing (like support for IRAs). Robinhood has been popular for a while because they popularized free trades and a good app. While the latter is subjective, most major brokerages have free trades and apps now. Fidelity is my choice which works well for index funds or individual stocks.

author: Zeddicus11
body: I started out with Robinhood, but then switched to Fidelity because their platform is more stable and developed, also offers mutual funds, allows opening a Roth IRA and checking account besides just a brokerage account, offers a great credit card etc. They also reimbursed me for the $75 Robinhood charged me to transfer all my stocks. RH seems great for relatively low stakes and experimenting with day trading in their nice looking app, whereas Fidelity (and Vanguard, and many other brokers) are more meant to be for long term investing and saving for retirement, rather than for day trading.

author: InvestingNerd2020
body: Fidelity is a far better choice for investing.  Good 24/7 customer service, fractional shares for all stocks/ETFs via mobile app, tax protected IRA accounts, far better charts for day trading, more reliable for Option trading, and zero expense ratio Index mutual funds for IRAs.
